text: My crystal ball tells me that machine learning has the best chances of developing into this direction. It doesn't really require Turing-style computing machines at the lowest level, so I expect very different hardware in the future. But the result will be something different from today's computers. Not better, not worse, different.

elements.text: My crystal ball tells me that machine learning has the best chances of developing into this direction. text:
Thank you <@UJBAJNFLK> for explaining the complexity issue and for the perspective of a different style of computing :ok_hand:
I agree with the idea of machine learning being a potential tool to reveal these patterns. I think it is because we have created so much software it becomes so difficult on the individual human level to see the patterns by themselves.

elements.text: for explaining the complexity issue and for the perspective of a different style of computing

I agree with the idea of machine learning being a potential tool to reveal these patterns. I think it is because we have created so much software it becomes so difficult on the individual human level to see the patterns by themselves.

text: I would even say that these two things: the formal and the informal approach to computing, they exist in a kind dialectic relationship. You need both! Thesis and Antithesis which form Synthesis which then becomes the next Thesis. I have a strong hunch that thus spiral will lead some very interesting insights and things. :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: I would even say that these two things: the formal and the informal approach to computing, they exist in a kind dialectic relationship. You need both! Thesis and Antithesis which form Synthesis which then becomes the next Thesis. I have a strong hunch that thus spiral will lead some very interesting insights and things.

text:
:100: We need both, and in fact we have always had both, but the dialectic relationship has never been properly equilibrated.
If you look at computers+users as socio-technical systems, it's humans that do most of the informal work. That's what I expect to change with machine learning. There are also interesting hybrids, such as differentiable programming.

elements.text:
We need both, and in fact we have always had both, but the dialectic relationship has never been properly equilibrated.
If you look at computers+users as socio-technical systems, it's humans that do most of the informal work. That's what I expect to change with machine learning. There are also interesting hybrids, such as differentiable programming.
